raw.text: This course is an introduction to the structure, function, evolution and biodiversity of unicellular eukaryotic organisms, including protozoa, microbial fungi and unicellular algae.  The ecology of free-living eukaryotic microbes and the immune responses of humans and other animals against pathogenic species will be discussed in detail.  Laboratories include experiments with live protozoa and microscopical observations of prepared microbes.
Prerequisites: BIOL1113/1123; BIOL2053 (Microbial diversity) and BIOL2073 (Animal biodiversity) are highly suggested.
For Fall 2008, lectures for this course are scheduled in slot 2 (Monday, Wednesday and Friday at 8:30-9:30), with laboratories scheduled in slot 26 (Monday at 1:30-4:30).

The tentative outline for the Fall 2008 session is detailed below.  This outline is only meant to give you an idea of which topics we might cover, but be warned that this is still tentative and that content may change at any time.
